content:
Embryology Course
Woods Hole, 1988
J. G. Gall
REFERENCES ON THE AMPHIBIAN GERMINAL VESICLE AND LAMPBRUSH CHROMOSOMES
Callan HG (1986) Lampbrush Chromosomes. Springer-Verlag (Vol. 36
in the series: Molecular Biology, Biochemistry, and Biophysics, ed. by
M. Solioz). A thorough, insightful analysis of all aspects of
lampbrush chromosome structure and function. Contains a complete
bibliography from the 19th century to the mid-1980's.
Amplification
Gall JG (1978) Early studies on gene amplification. The Harvey
Lectures, Series 71, pp. 55-70. Academic Press. Reviews the earlier
cytological evidence for gene amplification up to the first molecular
studies.
Gall JG (1968) Differential of the genes for ribosomal RNA
during amphibian oogenesis. Proc Natl Acad Sci QQ: 553-560. This and
the following paper provided the first molecular evidence for 
amplification.
Brown DD, Dawid IB (1968) Specific gene amplification in oocytes.
Science 160: 272-280.
Miller OL, Hamkalo BA (1972) Visualization of RNA on
chromosomes. International Review of Cytology 33: 1-25. One of many
places where Miller's famous electron micrographs are presented.
Bird AP (1980) Gene Reiteration and Gene Amplification. Ig: Cell
Biology, vol 3, pp. 61-111. Academic Press. A good general review.
RNA in Lampbrush Chromosomes
In addition to the references below, the topic is well covered in
Callan's book. 
The following two references review E.M. studies on transcription
units, among other topics.
Scheer U, Spring H, Trendelenburg MF (1979) Organization of
transcriptionally active chromatin in lampbrush chromosome loops. Ig:
The Cell Nucleus, vol 7, pp. 3-47. Edited by H. Busch. Academic
Press.
Beyer AL, McKnight SL, Miller OL (1979) Transcriptional units in
eukaryotic chromosomes. Ig: Molecular Genetics, Part pp. 117-
175. Edited by J. H. Taylor. Academic Press.
1
